thread.title: Bonds lower as US rate hike closes in
thread.title_full: Bonds lower as US rate hike closes in

title: Bonds lower as US rate hike closes in
text:
Thu, Jul 30, 2015, 8:51 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 1 hr 9 mins Bonds lower as US rate hike closes in AAP â€“ 7 minutes ago Print 
The bond market is weaker after the US Federal Reserve left the door open for its first rate increase in almost a decade. 
Markets took a risk-on approach to the Fed's widely expected decision overnight to leave interest rates unchanged, St George senior economist Hans Kunnen said. 
"The Fed sees continual growth, it's seeing inflation weak but moving in the right direction - the economy is fine," he said. 
"People then moved into equities and out of bonds. Bond yields rose a touch but not at an alarming rate." 
Mr Kunnen said the Fed's language suggested tightening would occur later this year. 
"The Fed is just setting the ground for a very modest rate hike in September or December and the markets are getting ready for that," he said. 
At 0830 AEST on Thursday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.150 (implying a yield of 2.850 per cent), down from 97.170 (2.830 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.060 (1.940 per cent), down from 98.100 (1.900 per cent). 
KEY MOVEMENTS: 
* CGS 5.5pct Jan 2018, 1.861%, unchanged from Wednesday 
* CGS 4.25pct April 2026, 2.877%, unchanged 
Sydney Futures Exchange prices: 
* September 2015 bill futures, 97.910, from 97.920 
* December 2015 bill futures, 97.960, from 97.980 
(*Closes taken at 1630 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
